prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not going to my best friends wedding.
So my best friend (lets call her G) has decided to have her wedding, that's awesome and I'm happy she found the one. 

The issue is G never sent out save the dates, meaning last week we got the actual wedding invitations for a wedding that is happening in 1 month.  

It will be at her grandmother's Ranch and it seems like a pretty nice wedding. 

here is where the issue started. 

a few months ago me and 3 friends decided to plan a trip to Australia to backpack/sightsee for 2 weeks, the trip starts 2 days before the wedding so we can't go. G knew about the trip as we invited her but I'm geussing she forgot. 
she is mad at all of us for not just cancelling the trip and being at her wedding. 

all of us are not super rich so this would be a huge loss if we cancelled the trip. (so we are not) 

I also want to add that she invited 50 people, I asked. and only 20 can make it as she gave 1 month notice. 

she is flipping her shit and acting like we should drop everything for her. 

AITA for not just cancelling my 2 week trip to go to her wedding? 
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let me try to figure this out. The user is asking if the person who wrote the AITA (Am I the Asshole) post is in the wrong for not attending their best friend's wedding.

First, the facts: The friend, G, didn't send save-the-dates and only sent invitations a month before the wedding. The person and their friends had already planned a trip to Australia that starts two days before the wedding. They couldn't cancel because it's a big financial loss. G is upset and expects them to drop everything.

So, was the writer wrong? Well, G didn't give much notice. A month is pretty short for a wedding, especially if you're expecting people to travel. The writer and friends had planned the trip months ago and invited G, who presumably forgot or didn't consider the timing. The writer isn't at fault for not being able to cancel last minute, especially with the financial aspect. Also, G invited 50 people but only 20 can make it, which shows maybe she didn't plan well. The writer's reasoning seems valid. The answer should be B.
